subhead: The US president formally requested the release of new documents related to Jeffrey Epstein. He also filed a defamation suit against 'The Wall Street Journal,' which published an article describing a lewd letter he is said to have sent to Epstein in 2003.

Secondhand medals reveal existence of Russian intelligence cyber units
subhead: A new report has analyzed public images of medals from the 16th Center of the Federal Security Service (FSB), Russia's internal intelligence branch responsible for communications espionage, uncovering valuable information about its organization.

title: A day off or not? Making sense of France's public holidays
subhead: With 11 public holidays each year, France falls slightly below the European average. Prime Minister François Bayrou has proposed scrapping two of them, arguing this would save €4.2 billion annually.
byline: By Romain Geoffroy, Romain Imbach, Pierre Breteau and Manon Romain

title: Paris brings back statues of pioneering women from 2024 Olympics ceremony
subhead: A statue of lawyer Gisèle Halimi, a champion of abortion rights, was among the first of the 10 statues presented last summer to be installed in northern Paris.

title: Pier Paolo Pasolini's mysterious death continues to haunt Italy, 50 years on
subhead: The murder of the Italian writer and filmmaker on November 2, 1975, still raises many questions. Among those who have not given up on the case, lawyer Stefano Maccioni fought for years to have judicial proceedings reopened. Now, he places his hopes in the parliamentary inquiry committee that has just been created.

title: Between rationing and a collaborationist past, the first holidays for Vichy's children after World War II
subhead: '1945, a French Summer' (5/6). In the aftermath of the war, the Vichy city council sought to restore the town's status as the 'capital of thermal spas.' At the same time, secular groups and religious institutions worked to offer children a summer break before the new school year began.

title: 'I regretted that road trip, which no doubt ended our relationship': How travel can strengthen or break bonds
subhead: For young couples or friends, the first vacation together often acts as a test. From deepened connections to breakups at highway rest stops, here are some stories about the delicate art of sharing an adventure.

title: These French villages have no more drinking water. The reason? PFAS pollution
subhead: Nearly 3,500 residents across 16 rural villages have been unable to drink tap water since July 10 due to a record-breaking contamination by PFAS, a group of toxic substances known as 'forever chemicals.'
byline: By Stéphane Mandard (Blagny, La Ferté-sur-Chiers, Villy, Han-lès-Juvigny and Stenay (eastern France), special correspondent)
